# Nitrogen-bridged Fe-Cu Atomic Pair Sites for Efficient Electrochemical Ammonia Production and Electricity Generation with  $\mathbf{Zn - NO}_2$  Batteries

Zhenghui  $B_i^+$ , Jiao  $H_u^+$ , Ming  $X_u^+$ , Hua Zhang, Yingtang Zhou,* and Guangzhi  $H_u^*$

Abstract The development of environmentally sustainable and highly efficient technologies for ammonia production is crucial for the future advancement of carbon- neutral energy systems. The nitrite reduction reaction  $(\mathrm{NO}_2\mathrm{RR})$  for generating  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  is a promising alternative to the low- efficiency nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR), owing to the low  $\mathrm{N} = \mathrm{O}$  bond energy and high solubility of nitrite. In this study, we designed a highly efficient dual- atom catalyst with Fe- Cu atomic pair sites (termed FeCu DAC), and the as- developed FeCu DAC was able to afford a remarkable  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  yield of  $24,526\mu \mathrm{g}\mathrm{h}^{- 1}$ $\mathrm{mg_{cat.}^{- 1}}$  at  $- 0.6\mathrm{V}$  with a Faradaic Efficiency (FE) for  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  production of  $99.88\%$ . The FeCu DAC also exhibited exceptional catalytic activity and selectivity in a  $\mathrm{Zn - NO}_2$  battery, achieving a record- breaking power density of  $23.6\mathrm{mWcm}^{- 1}$  and maximum  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  FE of  $92.23\%$  at  $20\mathrm{mAcm}^{- 2}$ . Theoretical simulation demonstrated that the incorporation of the  $\mathrm{Cu}$  atom changed the energy of the Fe 3d orbital and lowered the energy barrier, thereby accelerating the  $\mathrm{NO}_2\mathrm{RR}$ . This study not only demonstrates the potential of galvanic nitrite- based cells for expanding the field of  $\mathrm{Zn}$ - based batteries, but also provides fundamental interpretation for the synergistic effect in highly dispersed dual- atom catalysts.

# Introduction
title: 13.md

content:
# Introduction

Ammonia is a widely- used industrial product that serves as the primary raw material for manufacturing nitrogen- based fertilizers. It is considered an ideal carbon- free fuel for low- carbon energy technologies.[1] The Haber- Bosch process, conventionally used for synthesizing  $\mathrm{NH}_3$ , involves high pressure and temperature, leading to excessive energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.[2] In recent years, there has been extensive interest in using water as a hydrogen source for the electrochemical reduction of nitrogen to  $\mathrm{NH}_3$ , which allows the direct generation of  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  from  $\mathrm{N}_2$  and  $\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}$  under mild environmental conditions.[3] The outlook for the NRR appears grim due to the high energy required to cleave the non- polar  $\mathrm{N} \equiv \mathrm{N}$  bond  $(941\mathrm{kJ}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1})$  and low solubility of  $\mathrm{N}_2$  in most electrolytes, which promotes the competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and results in poor  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  selectivity and subpar current efficiency.[4] These problems severely limit the activity and selectivity of the NRR in aqueous media, which is a major constraint.  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  electrosynthesis can prospectively be realized via the  $\mathrm{NO}_2\mathrm{RR}$ , because of the substantially lower cleavage energy of the  $\mathrm{N} = \mathrm{O}$  bond  $(204\mathrm{kJ}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1})$  compared to that of the  $\mathrm{N} \equiv \mathrm{N}$  bond. In contrast with non- polar  $\mathrm{N}_2$ ,  $\mathrm{NO}_2^-$  has excellent solubility in water, making it an appealing nitrogen supply that can potentially accelerate the kinetics of  $\mathrm{NH}_3 / \mathrm{NH}_4^+$  formation.[5] Additionally,  $\mathrm{NO}_2^-$  undergoes greater electrocatalytic reduction in the same thermodynamic potential range as  $\mathrm{N}_2$ .[6]

Single- atom catalysts (SACs) have unique atomic structures and electronic properties that make them superior to bulk catalysts and nano catalysts. Researchers in the field of catalysis have shown great interest in SACs because of their remarkable activity and selectivity in many catalytic reactions.[7] The development of numerous  $\mathrm{NO}_2\mathrm{RR}$  electrocatalysts is now a priority. Homogeneous and heterogeneous SACs offer new prospects for electrocatalysis and represent a potential  $\mathrm{NO}_2\mathrm{RR}$  catalyst category. A significant number of pyrolytic SACs with an M- N- C (metal- nitrogen- carbon) structure have been studied for accelerating the  $\mathrm{NO}_2\mathrm{RR}$ .[8] Fe- N- C SACs have been extensively studied because of their low cost and excellent selectivity over a wide range of potential windows.[9] Furthermore, the electrocatalytic performance of Fe- N- C SACs can be fine- tuned by altering the coordination number or introducing vacancies to tune the electronic configuration of the Fe atom center.[10] Despite significant advances, the fundamentally stagnant kinetics of
title: 13.md

content:
# Introduction

the initial proton- coupled electron transfer at the Fe site strongly restricts the practical applicability of Fe- N- C SACs.[11] The construction of atom- pair structures has recently been considered an efficient method for modifying the activity of the catalytic sites, owing to cooperative electron modulation and the capability to overcome the limitations on the catalytic performance. However, because of a lack of intricate control mechanisms and thorough understanding of the structure of atom- pairs, the concept remains in its infancy and requires urgent advancement.

In this study, we strategically incorporate single Cu atoms into the microscopic structure of FeNC and finely adjust the 3d electronic configuration of the Fe site to augment its activity. However, Cu is considered an inert metal, and its presence can inhibit the competitive HER. In this regard, a nitrogen- bridged Fe- Cu atom pair was designed for achieving high- efficiency  $\mathrm{NO}_2\mathrm{RR}$  where the more electronegative Cu species is expected to raise the d- orbital energy level of the Fe active site, thereby strongly promoting the rate of the  $\mathrm{NO}_2\mathrm{RR}$ . In terms of the catalytic activity and selectivity, the as- developed two- atom center- site catalyst outperforms the single- atom congeners and previously investigated SACs. The innovative material, is utilized in a simple  $\mathrm{Zn - NO}_2$  battery device for the selective electroreduction of nitrogen oxyanions and synthesis of  $\mathrm{NH}_3$ .

# Results and Discussion

By using a straightforward liquid- phase deposition technique, completely exposed nitrogen- bridged Fe- Cu pairs were effectively created with theoretical loadings of Fe:  $1.69\mathrm{wt}\%$  and Cu:  $1.89\mathrm{wt}\%$  (Table S1). The morphology and structure of FeCu DAC was initially investigated using aberration- corrected high- angle annular dark- field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF- STEM). As highlighted by the orange ovals, the densely distributed bright dots represent the Fe- Cu atom pairs. As depicted in Figure 1a, ultrasmall Fe- Cu pairs were completely exposed and evenly dispersed on the carbon substrate, devoid of any crystallized iron or copper nanoparticles. The dispersion of several spot pairs with two distinct contrasts on the carbon matrix can be observed in the atomic- resolution HAADF- STEM images, which points to the presence of numerous Fe- Cu diatomic pairs in the matrix. The magnified HAADF- STEM images (Figure 1b) show several colored spots with distinctive contrast and brightness owing to the differing Z- axis contrasts of Fe and Cu, which were clustered together to generate atomic groups, each of which included an Fe atom and a neighboring Cu atom. Moreover, the corresponding energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping of FeCu DAC (Figure 1f) show the simultaneous presence of iron and copper species within cluster regions on the surface, indicating that the Fe- Cu pairs are mainly composed of completely exposed and widely dispersed Fe and Cu atoms.

# Results and Discussion

The X- ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the various catalysts revealed only the characteristic diffraction peaks of graphene, proving that no crystalline metal was generated, indicating the absence of Fe- or Cu- related crystal particles (Figure S6). In line with the STEM images of FeCu DAC, this offers definitive proof of the presence of highly dispersed Fe and Cu atomic structures in the cluster region. From the  $\mathbf{N}_2$  adsorption/desorption isotherm and pore distribution in Figure S9, the specific area of FeCu DAC was found to be large  $(687.5\mathrm{m}^2\mathrm{g}^{- 1})$  with numerous pores having a size of  $40\mathrm{nm}$  both of which are advantageous for exposure of the active sites and mass transfer of the electrolytes during the catalytic process.[12]

content:
# Results and Discussion

The electronic structure and local configuration of FeCu DAC were investigated using X- ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and synchrotron X- ray absorption fine- structure (XAFS) spectroscopy. The high- resolution N is XPS profile of FeCu DAC definitively proved the existence of oxidized N  $(402.6\mathrm{eV})$ , graphitic N  $(400.9\mathrm{eV})$ , and pyridinic N  $(398.3\mathrm{eV})$  (Figure S12). Notably, the spectrum of the metal- containing samples indicated the presence of other N species with a peak at  $399.9\mathrm{eV}$ , attributed to pyrrolic metal- N coordination.[13] Additional information the electronic interactions was acquired using X- ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectroscopy. Figure 2a shows the XANES spectrum at the Fe K- edge for FeCu DAC, FePc (iron phthalocyanine, with Fe- N groups), and FeO, as well as that of  $\mathrm{Fe}_2\mathrm{O}_3$  and Fe foil. The absorption edge position of FeCu DAC was between those of FePc and FeO, indicating that the average valence state of Fe was approximately  $+2$ . The local configuration around Fe was investigated using the Fourier transform (FT) of the extended X- ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectrum at the Fe K- edge (Figure 2c). The spectrum of FeCu DAC exhibits a maximum peak at  $1.53\mathrm{\AA}$ , matching the Fe- N first- shell coordination. There is no signal of the metallic Fe- Fe bond at  $2.12\mathrm{\AA}$  for FeCu DAC, again confirming the high dispersion of the metal atom. Excitingly, a distinct scattering path was observed at  $3.65\mathrm{\AA}$  in the spectrum of FeCu DAC, which is neither from Fe- N  $(1.53\mathrm{\AA})$  nor from metallic Fe- Fe  $(2.12\mathrm{\AA})$ . From EXAFS curve- fitting analysis, it is deduced that such a path could be reasonably attributed to the contribution of Fe- N- Cu (Figure 2e). The Cu K- edge XANES spectrum was examined to provide additional structural details. Cu is in an average valence state that is positively charged (Figure 2b), where the edge position was close to that of the  $2+$  valence state of CuPc (copper phthalocyanine, with Cu- N groups). The Cu K- edge FT- EXAFS spectrum of FeCu DAC (Figure 2d), showed a main peak at  $1.56\mathrm{\AA}$ , which is obviously different from the dominant peak at  $2.24\mathrm{\AA}$  for Cu foil originating from the Cu- Cu bond. Furthermore, a tiny peak was also observed at  $3.47\mathrm{\AA}$  in the spectrum of FeCu DAC at the Cu K- edge, similar to that observed at the Fe K- edge, the presence of which offers compelling proof of the Fe- N- Cu bond. Wavelet transform (WT) analysis, which enables high- resolution visualisation of the R- space, was executed to further confirm the existence of the Fe- N- Cu path (Figure 2g). The WT contour plot of Fe foil, shows an intensity maximum at  $7.17\mathrm{\AA}^{- 1}$  attributed to the Fe- Fe contribution, whereas no maximum was observed in the spectrum of FeCu DAC, demonstrating the absence of crystalline metal clusters in

Almost all of the characteristics of the experimental spectra data were accurately reproduced, indicating the reasonable existence of the  $\mathrm{FeCuN}_7$  configuration.

# Results and Discussion

To examine the electrocatalytic activity of various catalysts for the  $\mathrm{NO}_2\mathrm{RR}$ , initial screening tests were carried out in  $\mathrm{Ar}_2$ - saturated  $0.1\mathrm{M}$  KOH solution. First, linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) data were acquired in KOH electrolyte with and without  $\mathrm{NaNO}_2$  to investigate the catalytic performance of FeCu DAC for nitrite reduction (Figure 3a). The noticeably increased current density at the same potential indicates that  $\mathrm{NO}_2^-$  ions can be efficiently depleted by FeCu DAC. The ammonia yield rate was determined in the  $\mathrm{KOH / NaNO}_2$  electrolyte by maintaining a different potential for  $1\mathrm{h}$  each time, and the synthesized  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  products were quantified using ultraviolet- visible (UV/Vis) spectrophotometry. As shown in Figure 3b, FeCu DAC exhibited excellent selectivity and a remarkable yield rate for  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  conversion via the electrocatalysis of  $\mathrm{NO}_2^-$ .  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  production was observed at  $- 0.4\mathrm{V}$  vs. RHE from the beginning of the reaction, with a FE of  $95.11\%$ , corresponding to a yield rate of  $16,250\mu \mathrm{g}\mathrm{h}^{- 1}\mathrm{mg}_{\mathrm{cat.}}^{- 1}$ . The  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  selectivity reached a maximum of  $99.88\%$  at  $- 0.6\mathrm{V}$ , representing a yield rate of  $24,526\mu \mathrm{g}\mathrm{h}^{- 1}\mathrm{mg}_{\mathrm{cat.}}^{- 1}$ . A significant partial  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  FE of  $96.74\%$  was obtained at  $- 0.8\mathrm{V}$ , delivering a superior yield rate of  $29,382\mu \mathrm{g}\mathrm{h}^{- 1}\mathrm{mg}_{\mathrm{cat.}}^{- 1}$ . The FE and yield rate of FeCu DAC were orders of magnitude higher than those in previous research (Figure 3c) because of the drastically different kinetic energy barriers to

# Results and Discussion

surmount. Moreover, the ammonia- generating performance of the  $\mathrm{FeCuN}_7$  active site is outstanding compared to that of other  $\mathrm{NO}_2\mathrm{RR}$  systems that typically employ bulk or nanocluster metal catalysts. To investigate the active sites on FeCu DAC, a control experiment was performed with Fe and Cu atoms supported on a carbon substrate for comparison with FeCu DAC (Figure S19). The Fe and Cu SACs exhibited much lower  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  activity than FeCu DAC. Additionally, commercial FePc and CuPc displayed inferior catalytic performance compared to that of Fe SAC and Cu SAC, respectively. The endurance of FeCu DAC in the  $\mathrm{NO}_2\mathrm{RR}$  was evaluated in eight consecutive electrochemical cycles using a H- cell reactor (Figure S20). The  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  yield rate and  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  FE fluctuated between cycles, but remained stable in each cycle, indicating the outstanding stability of FeCu DAC.

In light of these evidences, a  $\mathrm{Zn - NO}_2$  battery was constructed and a series of electrocatalytic experiments was performed to comprehensively evaluate the effectiveness of the catalysts for the electrochemical  $\mathrm{NO}_2\mathrm{RR}$  in a  $\mathrm{Zn}$ - based battery using a catalyst- supported carbon cloth as the cathode and an inexpensive  $\mathrm{Zn}$  plate as the anode.[14] As demonstrated by the photograph of the  $\mathrm{Zn - NO}_2$  battery in

# Results and Discussion

Figure 3d, the anode with the  $1\mathrm{M}$  KOH electrolyte and the cathode with  $0.1\mathrm{M}$ $\mathrm{KOH} + 0.1\mathrm{M}$ $\mathrm{NaNO}_2$  were directly separated by a proton exchange membrane. The  $\mathrm{Zn - NO}_2$  system electrocatalytically reduces  $\mathrm{NO}_2$  to  $\mathrm{NH}_3$ , driven by dissolution of the  $\mathrm{Zn}$  plate during the discharge process. The measured open- circuit voltage of this  $\mathrm{Zn - NO}_2$  battery was  $1.463\mathrm{V}$ , with excellent stability over  $6\mathrm{h}$ . The output current increased progressively as the negative voltage increased, and the representative power density reached a peak value of  $23.6\mathrm{mWcm}^{- 2}$  (Figure 3e). However, the Fe SAC- based counterpart afforded a lower maximum power density of only  $13.9\mathrm{mWcm}^{- 2}$ . As determined from the discharge curves, at output current densities of 5, 10, and  $20\mathrm{mAcm}^{- 2}$ , the  $\mathrm{Zn - NO}_2$  battery equipped with the FeCu DAC provided specific capacitances of 744.9, 753.7, and  $759.4\mathrm{mAhg}^{- 1}\mathrm{Zn}$  normalized to the mass of  $\mathrm{Zn}$  consumed, corresponding to  $\mathrm{Zn}$  utilization ratios of  $90.8\%$ ,  $91.9\%$ , and  $92.6\%$ , respectively (Figure 3f). Upon discharging for  $1\mathrm{h}$  at different current densities (Figure 3g and 3h), the  $\mathrm{Zn}$ - based battery achieved high  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  FE of  $89.27\%$  and a high  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  yield of  $9,435\mu \mathrm{g}\mathrm{h}^{- 1}\mathrm{mg}_{\mathrm{cat.}}^{- 1}$  at  $20\mathrm{mAcm}^{- 2}$ , determined from the calibration curve for the specified  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  concentrations (Figure S22). As anticipated, the battery exhibited an ultrahigh current efficiency of  $92.23\%$  at a steady current density of  $20\mathrm{mAcm}^{- 2}$  with a  $\mathrm{NH_3}$  yield rate of  $9,749\mu \mathrm{g}\mathrm{h}^{- 1}\mathrm{mg}_{\mathrm{cat.}}^{- 1}$ . Overall, we effectively designed and demonstrated a  $\mathrm{Zn}$ - based battery that can simultaneously achieve high energy output and efficient  $\mathrm{NH_3}$  production.
title: 13.md

content:
# Results and Discussion

According to previous reports, the  $\mathrm{NO_2RR}$  involves a series of deoxidation and hydrogenation reactions. In order to gain a deeper understanding of the origin of the exceptional catalytic activity on the  $\mathrm{FeCuN_7}$  site, we conducted density functional theory (DFT) calculations to delve into the fundamental mechanism of the  $\mathrm{NO_2RR}$ , where the Fe site is considered rather than the Cu because of the higher intrinsic activity of the former. Based on the projected density of states (PDOS) in Figure 4a and 4b, the introduction of the  $\mathrm{Cu}$  atom resulted in an upward shift of the d- band center from  $- 1.55\mathrm{eV}$ $\mathrm{(FeN_4)}$  to  $- 1.48\mathrm{eV}$ $\mathrm{(FeCuN_7)}$  thereby enhancing N- intermediate adsorption.[16] Besides, the electron localization function (ELF) was applied to further evaluate the degree of electronic delocalization of the  $\mathrm{FeCuN_7}$ .[17] As plotted in Figure 4c and 4d, it confirmed that the presence of chemical bonds on the interface and electrons localized the distribution of the  $\mathrm{FeCuN_7}$ . The 2D slices showed that the chemical bonds of Fe and N, as well as Cu and N, in the  $\mathrm{FeCuN_7}$  supercell were assigned to Fe- N and Cu- N bonds. The  $\mathrm{FeCuN_7}$  presented a larger region area around Fe- N atoms than that of  $\mathrm{FeN_4}$  in ELF, implying that the  $\mathrm{FeCuN_7}$  has richer delocalized electrons. Moreover, it was evident that there existed a significant electron accumulation at the Fe atoms surrounding Cu depicted in Figure 4e and 4f, which can act as electron reservoirs and facilitate the deoxygenation and hydrogenation reactions. In addition, the Gibbs free- energy diagram (Figure 4g and Table S4) revealed that the  $\mathrm{NO_2RR}$  included deoxygenation  $(^{*}\mathrm{NO}_{2}\rightarrow^{*}\mathrm{NO}\rightarrow^{*}\mathrm{N})$  and hydrogenation  $(^{*}\mathrm{N}\rightarrow^{*}\mathrm{NH}\rightarrow^{*}\mathrm{NH}_{2}\rightarrow^{*}\mathrm{NH}_{3})$  steps. On  $\mathrm{FeN_4}$ , the step with the highest Gibbs free- energy change  $(\Delta \mathrm{G})$  was  $^{*}\mathrm{N}\rightarrow^{*}\mathrm{NH}$ , with an energy barrier of  $0.74\mathrm{eV}$ . Strikingly, the  $\Delta \mathrm{G}$  for  $^{*}\mathrm{N}\rightarrow^{*}\mathrm{NH}$  on the  $\mathrm{FeCuN_7}$  was only  $0.49\mathrm{eV}$ , which was a potential-

determining step for both the  $\mathrm{FeN}_4$  and  $\mathrm{FeCuN}_7$ . Furthermore, the barrier for transition- state (TS) formation during  $\mathrm{^*NO}$  and HNO dissociation was also reduced on the  $\mathrm{FeCuN}_7$ . It was also found that energy changes from  $\mathrm{^*NO}_2$  to  $\mathrm{^*N}$  were an exothermic process, which means that  $\mathrm{NO}_2^-$  can be adsorbed on the  $\mathrm{FeCuN}_7$  surface spontaneously. Then, the  $\mathrm{^*NO}_2$  was cleaved step by step to form  $\mathrm{^*N}$ , which was then transformed into  $\mathrm{^*NH}_4$  through a series of endothermic and exothermic processes. Furthermore, as shown in Figure S27, under alkaline conditions,  $\mathrm{FeN}_4$  need to overcome higher number of energy barriers compared to  $\mathrm{FeCuN}_7$  during water dissociation, thereby impeding hydrogen production. Consequently, the preference for  $\mathrm{NO}_2\mathrm{RR}$  lies with  $\mathrm{FeCuN}_7$  over  $\mathrm{FeN}_4$ . In short, the incorporation of the  $\mathrm{Cu}$  atom modified the electronic property of the Fe atom and thus reduced the thermodynamic energy barriers of key steps for  $\mathrm{NO}_2\mathrm{RR}$ . This particular Fe- Cu configuration stimulates the electron redistribution of Fe to promote catalytic conversion of the intermediates, ultimately accelerating the electrocatalytic  $\mathrm{NO}_2\mathrm{RR}$ . These findings provide crucial directions for future efforts to modify or redesign Fe- based active sites using multiple strategies.

# Conclusion
title: 13.md

content:
# Conclusion

In conclusion, we rationally developed a novel FeCu DAC material exhibiting exceptional electrocatalytic properties for the direct nitrite electroreduction process in ammonia production. The DFT simulation reveals that the introduction of  $\mathrm{Cu}$  leads to a reconstruction of the electronic structure of Fe in the FeCu DAC, effectively shifting the d- band center towards the Fermi level. This modification significantly enhances the capacity of Fe for adsorption of the intermediates and reduces reaction barriers, resulting in an unprecedented  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  yield of  $24,526 \mu \mathrm{g} \mathrm{h}^{- 1} \mathrm{mg}_{\mathrm{cat}}^{- 1}$  at  $- 0.6 \mathrm{~V}$  and a remarkable  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  FE of  $99.88\%$ . Owing to the electron- rich  $\mathrm{NO}_2\mathrm{RR}$  and excellent catalytic performance of FeCu DAC, a  $\mathrm{Zn - NO}_2$  battery system was established with the FeCu DAC cathode and a metal  $\mathrm{Zn}$  anode. The constructed  $\mathrm{Zn - NO}_2$  battery can simultaneously produce ammonia and generate electricity, with a power density of  $23.6 \mathrm{mW} \mathrm{cm}^{- 2}$  and a high  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  FE of  $92.23\%$  at  $20 \mathrm{mA} \mathrm{cm}^{- 2}$ . This study not only proposes a novel theory for purposefully tuning the catalytic performance of atom- dispersed metal catalysts, but also deepens the fundamental understanding of the synergistic effects in heterogeneous dual- atom catalysts. Furthermore, we have experimentally validated the effectiveness of galvanic nitrite- based battery, thereby

providing a viable method for  $\mathrm{NH_3}$  production and advancing the field of Zn- based batteries.

content:
# Coordination Symmetry Breaking of Single-Atom Catalysts for Robust and Efficient Nitrate Electroreduction to Ammonia

Xue- Feng Cheng, Jing- Hui He,* Hao- Qing Ji, Hao- Yu Zhang, Qiang Cao, Wu- Ji Sun, Cheng- Lin Yan, and Jian- Mei Lu*

Nitrate electrocatalytic reduction  $(NO_3RR)$  for ammonia production is a promising strategy to close the N- cycle from nitration contamination, as well as an alternative to the Haber- Bosch process with less energy consumption and carbon dioxide release. However, current long- term stability of  $NO_3RR$  catalysts is usually tens of hours, far from the requirements for industrialization. Here, symmetry- broken Cusingle- atom catalysts are designed, and the catalytic activity is retained after operation for more than  $2000h$  while an average ammonia production rate of  $27.84\mathrm{mg h^{- 1} cm^{- 2}}$  at an industrial level current density of  $366\mathrm{mA cm^{- 2}}$  is achieved, obtaining a good balance between catalytic activity and long- term stability. Coordination symmetry breaking is achieved by embedding one Cu atom in graphene nanosheets with two N and two O atoms in the cis- configuration, effectively lowering the coordination symmetry, rendering the active site more polar, and accumulating more  $NO_3^-$  near the electrocatalyst surface. Additionally, the cis- coordination splits the Cu 3d orbitals, which generates an orbital- symmetry- matched  $\pi$  - complex of the key intermediate \*ONH and reduces the energy barrier, compared with the  $\sigma$  - complex generated with other catalysts. These results reveal the critical role of coordination symmetry in single- atom catalysts, prompting the design of more coordinationsymmetry- broken electrocatalysts toward possible industrialization.

# 1. Introduction

Accumulation of nitrate  $(NO_3^- )$  in groundwater causes photochemical smog and acid rain, and the in vivo conversion of  $NO_3^-$  to nitrite  $(NO_2^- )$  further induces methemoglobinemia and cancers.[1] Thus, closing the  $NO_3^- = N$  cycle by electrochemically reducing nitrate to a valued product ammonia, is promising for reducing carbon dioxide  $(CO_2)$  release and for environmental remediation.[2] In addition, ammonia  $(NH_3)$  as one of the most common chemical feedstocks[3] is mainly produced by the Haber- Bosch method, involving the reaction of  $N_2$  and  $H_2$  at high temperatures, accompanied by  $1 - 2\%$  energy consumption and  $CO_2$  release.[4] Therefore, the nitrate electrochemical reduction reaction  $(NO_3RR)$  to ammonia, has recently attracted intensive interest because of the high water solubility of  $NO_3^-$  and the low dissociation energy of the  $N = O$  bond  $(204\mathrm{kJ mol^{- 1}})$  of  $NO_3^-$ .[3a] Numerous noble metal nanoparticles,[2a,3] metal oxides,[10] and 2D materials[7] have been prepared and demonstrated their promising  $NO_3RR$  performance. Even though relatively high catalytic activity was obtained,[2a,8] only a few works focused on improving the catalytic stability.[9] Long- term stability of cata lyst is a more important factor towards real applications,[10] as deactivation of initially activated electrocatalysts after long- term operation due to passivation, leaching, and corrosion often occurs in industrialization.[9,11]
title: 15.md

content:
# 1. Introduction

Single- atom catalysts, owing to their maximum atom efficiency, tunable metal centers, and coordination environments,[12] have attracted growing interest in electrocatalysis, including electrochemical  $CO_2$  reduction,[13] hydrogen evolution,[14] and oxygen reduction.[15] The fully exposed active sites and strong interactions between single atoms and the surrounding coordination atoms endow single- atom catalysts with superior activity and appreciable stability.[15b,16] However, the isolated metal centers of most single- atom electrocatalysts coordinate with four N atoms in  $C_{4v}$  symmetry.[15a,17] These weakly polar active sites exhibit relatively weak attraction to  $NO_3^-$  ions, leading to weak ion migration, and consequently low ammonia production rates.[9,18] Thermodynamically,  $NO_3RR$  involves multiple steps, with the transfer of eight electrons and nine protons.[2b,19] Once adsorption on the catalyst surface is weak, the intermediate  $*NO_2$  may be desorbed from the catalyst surface and move to the electrolyte, resulting in the accumulation of more toxic nitrite.[3a,7,20] Therefore, substituting part of the coordinated N with weakly coordinated O/S atoms will break

the coordination symmetry of the metal centers and increase the site polarity,[21] which is expected to be an effective approach for improving  $\mathrm{NO}_3^-$  accumulation. In particular, breaking the coordination symmetry by substituting two N atoms with heteroatoms causes the remaining two N to adopt cis- or transconfigurations, leaving room for further modulation of the electronic properties of the metal center.

In this work, we demonstrate that by breaking the coordination symmetry of Cu single- atom catalysts (SACs) by substituting the local coordination atoms from 4N to  $2N + 20$  the stability of the  $\mathrm{NO}_3\mathrm{RR}$  electrocatalysts can be greatly improved. A model electrocatalyst with Cu coordinated by two N and two O atoms in the cis- configuration  $(\mathrm{Cu - cis - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2)$  is prepared by annealing Salen- Cu coordination polymers. The symmetry- broken  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  SAC strikes a good balance between catalytic activity and long- term stability. The ammonia production rate reaches  $2784\mathrm{mg}\cdot \mathrm{h}^{- 1}\mathrm{cm}^{- 2}$  with an industrial- level current density of  $366\mathrm{mAcm}^{- 2}$  and the catalytic activity is well preserved after operation for more than  $2000\mathrm{h}$  (Table S1, Supporting Information). Compared to 4N- coordinated Cu SAC  $(\mathrm{Cu - N_4})$  and Cu- trans-  $\mathrm{N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  (Cu coordinated by two N and two O atoms in the trans- configuration),  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  lowers down the coordination symmetry, rendering the active site more polar. Thus, more  $\mathrm{NO}_3^-$  can be accumulated near the electrocatalyst surface. In addition, the cis coordination splits the Cu 3d orbitals, allowing the formation of an orbital symmetry- matched  $\pi$  complex of the key reaction intermediate  $\mathrm{^*ONH}$  rather than the conventional  $\sigma$  complex, where the former reduces the formation energy barrier, as revealed by density functional theory calculations. This unprecedentedly long- term stability with continuously ammonia production step forward the practical applications.

# 2. Results and Discussions
title: 15.md

content:
# 2. Results and Discussions

To theoretically investigate the coordination symmetry effect, Cu atoms were embedded in a graphene monolayer sheet by bonding with four N atoms  $(\mathrm{Cu - N_4})$  or with two N and two O atoms in trans-  $(\mathrm{Cu - trans - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  two N atoms on opposite sides) or cis- configuration (two N atoms on the same side,  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2)$  respectively). Nitrate adsorption was first simulated through molecular dynamics by immersing the  $\mathrm{Cu - N_4}$ $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2,$  and  $\mathrm{Cu - trans - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  model catalysts in aqueous  $\mathrm{KNO}_3$  solution. Compared to  $\mathrm{Cu - N_4}$  both  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  and Cu- trans-  $\mathrm{N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  attracted a higher concentration of  $\mathrm{NO}_3^-$  ions from the electrolyte to the side of interface after 50 ns (Figure 1b- d), judging from the radial distribution centered at the Cu atoms (Figure 1e). Furthermore, with respect to the radial distribution of  $\mathrm{NO}_3^-$  centered at the coordinating  $\mathrm{O / N}$  atoms around all the Cu SACs,  $\mathrm{NO}_3^-$  was most sharply concentrated at the O side in  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  (Figure 1f), indicating that the O side has the highest  $\mathrm{NO}_3^-$  accumulation ability. During the electrochemical reaction, this enhanced accumulation ability could significantly improve the reaction rate.

Coordination symmetry breaking in SACs also effectively improves the reaction kinetics by modulating the formation barrier of the key intermediate  $\mathrm{^*ONH}$  As revealed by the present and other previous density functional theory (DFT) calculations,
title: 15.md

content:
# 2. Results and Discussions

$\mathrm{NO}_3\mathrm{RR}$  undergoes nine elementary steps involving the transfer of eight electrons and nine protons.[2a,20] Taking  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  as an example, the reaction is initiated when nitrate ions are adsorbed on the Cu SACs, with a free energy of formation of  $- 2.36\mathrm{eV}$  (refer to the initial interaction- free state). Thereafter,  $\mathrm{^*NO}_3$  reacts with protons and electrons, breaking the  $\mathrm{N} - \mathrm{O}$  bond step by step to form  $\mathrm{^*NO}_2$  and  $\mathrm{^*NO}$  The further reduction of  $\mathrm{^*NO}$  can proceed via two possible pathways.[22] The proton- electron pair could attack  $\mathrm{^*NO}$  through either the O or N side, proceeding through the NOH and ONH pathways, respectively. From  $\mathrm{^*NO}\rightarrow \mathrm{^*NOH}$  the calculated formation barrier is  $1.23\mathrm{eV}$  which is larger than the energy barrier for the  $\mathrm{^*NO}\rightarrow \mathrm{^*ONH}$  process  $(0.39\mathrm{eV})$  . Therefore, the ONH pathway is more favorable. Subsequently,  $\mathrm{^*ONH}$  species are continuously reduced to  $\mathrm{^*ONH_2}$  and  $\mathrm{^*ONH_2}$  with negative  $\Delta G$  values. With the release of  $\mathrm{NH}_3,$ $\mathrm{^*OH}$  is formed and then transformed into  $\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}$  .Overviewing the entire nitrate reduction process,  $\mathrm{^*NO}\rightarrow \mathrm{^*ONH}$  is the rate- determining step with the highest formation barrier (Figure 2a).

The proposed reaction pathways were verified using in situ online differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) to detect the reaction intermediates. The catalyst slurry was pasted onto a porous polytetrafluoroethylene membrane, the back side of which was exposed to the mass spectrometer (MS), allowing the penetration of various gaseous products into the MS for further detection. When four voltage pulses from  $0\mathrm{V}$  to  $- 1.8\mathrm{V}$  were applied to the  $\mathrm{NO}_3\mathrm{RR}$  electrocatalyst, signals appeared at  $m / z$  17, 30, 33, and 46, corresponding to the mentioned species  $\mathrm{NH}_3,\mathrm{NO},\mathrm{ONH}_3,$  and  $\mathrm{NO}_2,$  respectively (Figure S1, Supporting Information). The existence of these intermediates, the relatively strong  $\mathrm{NH}_3$  signal, and the weak  $\mathrm{NO}_2$  signal confirm the reasonability of the proposed reaction pathways.
title: 15.md

content:
# 2. Results and Discussions

The reaction pathways at the Cu- trans-  $\mathrm{N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  and  $\mathrm{Cu - N_4}$  sites were then calculated and the key energy barriers were compared with those of  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  .In the initial adsorption stage (Figure S2), the energy for the adsorption of nitrate on  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$ $(- 2.36\mathrm{eV})$  and  $\mathrm{Cu - trans - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$ $(- 2.02\mathrm{eV})$  was much higher than for adsorption on  $\mathrm{Cu - N_4}$ $(- 1.17\mathrm{eV})$  . Such strong adsorptive interactions with nitrate are consistent with molecular dynamics simulation, proving the first important coordination symmetry breaking effect when  $2\mathrm{N} + 2\mathrm{O}$  atoms replace 4N atoms. In addition,  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  possesses a much higher barrier  $(2.60\mathrm{eV})$  than  $\mathrm{Cu - trans - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$ $(- 2.20\mathrm{eV})$  and  $\mathrm{Cu - N_4}$ $(1.36\mathrm{eV})$  , hindering the release of toxic  $\mathrm{NO}_2^-$  ions during the reaction. More importantly, while the rate- determining step is also  $\mathrm{^*NO}$ $\mathrm{^*ONH}$  in the ONH pathway,  $\Delta G$  for this step on  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  was calculated as  $0.39\mathrm{eV},$  which is much lower than that for the reaction on  $\mathrm{Cu - trans - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$ $(0.51\mathrm{eV},$  Figure 2b); both values are lower than for the reaction on  $\mathrm{Cu - N_4}$ $(0.69\mathrm{eV},$  Figure 2c). To roughly eliminate the electrostatic attractive force, the first adsorbed state on the three electrocatalysts was set as the reference level. The discrepancies in the formation energies (Table S2, Supporting Information) reveal that  $\mathrm{^*ONH}$  on  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  is further stabilized by the formation of a  $\pi$  complex (zoomed- in configuration in Figure 2a).

It is further demonstrated herein that the coordination symmetry breaking induced by substitution with O distorts the Cu 3d orbital splitting. In  $\mathrm{Cu - N_4}$ $\mathrm{Cu}$  is equivalently coordinated by four N atoms with a  $\mathrm{Cu - N}$  bond length of  $1.93\mathrm{\AA}$  .When

content:
# 2. Results and Discussions

O atoms were embedded to replace two N atoms in Cu- trans $\mathrm{N}_2\mathrm{O}_2,$  the  $\mathrm{Cu - O}$  bond length was  $2.05\mathrm{\AA},$  and the  $\mathrm{Cu - N}$  bond contracted to  $1.91\mathrm{\AA}$  . The  $\mathrm{Cu - N}$  bond was further strengthened by shortening to  $1.87\mathrm{\AA}$  when two O atoms were on the same side in  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$  . These symmetry breakings are attributable to the much weaker coordination ability of O compared to N in nature and the saturated form O atoms  $(- O - )$  in the graphene matrix. We also calculated the energy barrier of  $\mathrm{^*NO\rightarrow^*ONH}$  in ONH path  $(\Delta G_{\ast \mathrm{NO}\rightarrow \ast \mathrm{ONH}})$  in  $\mathrm{Cu - N_3O_1}$ $\mathrm{Cu - N_1O_3},$  and  $\mathrm{Cu - O_4}$  SACs (Figure S6a, Supporting Information). With the increase of coordinating O atoms,  $\Delta G_{\mathrm{RDS}}$  gradually decreases, indicating the increase in catalytic activity. While the stability of Cu SACs gradually decreases because of weaker coordination ability of O atoms. Taking both catalytic activity and long- term stability into consideration, partially substituted  $\mathrm{Cu - N_2O_2}$  SACs may be able to balance these two factors well. Furthermore, the coordination symmetry breaking also has comparable contribution to the decrease of  $\Delta G_{\ast \mathrm{NO}\rightarrow \ast \mathrm{ONH}}$  .Cu- trans-  $\mathrm{N}_2\mathrm{O}_2,$  with higher coordination symmetry has similar  $\Delta G_{\ast \mathrm{NO}\rightarrow \ast \mathrm{ONH}}$  to that of  $\mathrm{Cu - N_3O_1}$  . While the breaking- symmetry Cu- cis-  $\mathrm{N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  possesses relatively lower  $\Delta G_{\ast \mathrm{NO}\rightarrow \ast \mathrm{ONH}}$  comparable to that of  $\mathrm{Cu - N_1O_3}$  (Figure S6b, Supporting Information). The partial density of states of the Cu 3d orbitals in  $\mathrm{Cu - N_4}$  and two types of  $\mathrm{Cu - N_2O_2}$  SAC systems was calculated (Figure 2d- f), and an H- terminated finite cluster model was used to visualize these orbitals (Figure S8, Supporting Information). In  $\mathrm{Cu - N_4}$ $\mathrm{d}_{x^2 - y^2}$  is raised to the highest occupied d- orbital owing to the strong coordination of the N atoms. In both Cu- trans-  $\mathrm{N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  and Cu- cis $\mathrm{N}_2\mathrm{O}_2,$  all Cu 3d orbitals fell below the Fermi level and were fully occupied. In  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$ $\mathrm{d}_{x^2 - y^2}$  is essentially the highest occupied d- orbital, despite slight coupling with other 3d orbitals, whereas in Cu- trans-  $\mathrm{N}_2\mathrm{O}_2,$  the highest d orbital is  $\mathrm{d}_{z^2}$  - like

# 2. Results and Discussions

Figure 2. a-c) Reaction pathway for  $\mathrm{NO_3^-}$  reduction to  $\mathrm{NH_3}$  on the surface of Cu-cis-  $\mathrm{N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  (a), Cu-trans-  $\mathrm{N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  (b), and  $\mathrm{Cu - N_4}$  SAC (c). d-f) Calculated d-band centers of Cu-cis-  $\mathrm{N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  (d), Cu-trans-  $\mathrm{N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  (e), and  $\mathrm{Cu - N_4}$  SAC (f).

because of the strong coordination from  $\mathrm{N}$  in the opposite direction. Considering ONH as an unsaturated molecule for which the LUMO has  $\pi^*$  symmetry (Figure S8, Supporting Information), the highest  $\mathrm{d}_{x^2 - y^2}$  orbital was available as a symmetry and energy- matched donor for the  $\pi^*$  orbital of ONH to form a  $\pi$ - complex only in the case of  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$ ; this interaction weakens the  $\mathrm{O - N}$  bonding in ONH and facilitates further hydrogenation.
title: 15.md

content:
# 2. Results and Discussions

Inspired by the theoretical analysis,  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$  single- atom catalysts were prepared by the pyrolysis of 1D organic- inorganic chains, where the Salen ligand was used as a matrix for dispersing and coordinating  $\mathrm{Cu}$  ions in an exact  $cis - \mathrm{N}_2\mathrm{O}_2$  configuration (Figure 3a). During pyrolysis, the good planarity and  $\mathrm{sp}^2$  hybridization of carbon were beneficial for preserving the  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$  configuration. Interconversion between the cis and trans configurations during pyrolysis is intuitively difficult because of the need to break multiple  $\mathrm{C - O}$  and  $\mathrm{C - N}$  bonds simultaneously. The porous structure of the 1D organic- inorganic chains was well preserved after pyrolysis under the protection of Ar (Figures S5 and S10, Supporting Information). When the Cu- to- Salen molar ratio of the reactants decreased, the content of copper nanoparticles in the carbonized catalyst gradually decreased (Figure 3b). Once the Cu- to- Salen molar ratio in the reactants decreased to  $3\%$ , no copper nanoparticles were formed (Figures S11 and S12, Supporting Information), and this ratio was chosen for subsequent experiments. The aberration- corrected high- angle annular dark- field scanning transmission electron microscopy image confirms the existence of isolated  $\mathrm{Cu}$  single atoms dispersed on the porous carbon matrix (Figure 3d). Energy- dispersive X- ray spectroscopy mapping analysis confirmed the existence and uniform distribution of  $\mathrm{Cu}$ ,  $\mathrm{N}$ ,  $\mathrm{O}$ , and  $\mathrm{C}$  throughout the catalyst (Figure 3f). The final  $\mathrm{Cu}$  loading in SAC was about  $5.04 \mathrm{wt\%}$  based on inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP- AES) analysis. Furthermore,  $\mathrm{Ru - cis - N_2O_2}$  and  $\mathrm{Fe - cis - N_2O_2}$  single- atom catalysts were prepared by only changing the metal

![](images/e014bc75dbf17ac08a75e283217ccfd4850d5466af4854beca67c0848ed93976.jpg)  
Figure 3. a) Synthetic process of  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$  single atom catalyst. b) XRD patterns of pyrolytic Salen-Cu polymers with different Cu-to-Salen molar ratios in reactants. c) HRTEM image, d,e) HAADF-STEM image, and f) elemental maps for  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$  single atom.

salts (Figures S13- S15, Supporting Information), demonstrating that the developed method is an effective and universal strategy for preparing  $\mathrm{M - cis - N_2O_2}$  - type single- atom catalysts.
title: 15.md

content:
# 2. Results and Discussions

X- ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to investigate the structure of the  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$  SACs. The signals of Cu, C, N, and O were detected in the profiles of both the Salen- Cu precursors and  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$  SAC. The deconvoluted high- resolution N 1 s spectra confirm preservation of the  $\mathrm{Cu - N}$  bond  $(399.2\mathrm{eV})$  and the generation of pyridinic N and graphitic N after pyrolysis (Figure 4a).[23] The signal of the  $\mathrm{C} = \mathrm{O}$  double bond was deconvoluted from the high- resolution O 1 s spectrum (Figure 4b), as well as the C 1 s spectrum (Figure 4c) after pyrolysis. During the initial preparation of Salen- Cu, the Salen ligand centers in the 1D chains did not fully coordinate with the copper ions. These empty Salen ligand centers may produce a  $- \mathrm{C} = \mathrm{O}$  moiety during pyrolysis.

Synchrotron- based X- ray absorption near- edge structure (XANES) and extended X- ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra were obtained to further validate the coordination configuration of  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$  SAC. The Cu K- edge XANES spectra show that the energy absorption threshold of  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$  SAC is located between those of  $\mathrm{Cu_2O}$  and  $\mathrm{CuO}$ , suggesting that the valence state of  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$  SAC is situated between those of  $\mathrm{Cu^{+}}$  and  $\mathrm{Cu^{2 + }}$  (Figure 4d). The fitted oxidation state of  $\mathrm{Cu}$  in  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$  from the K- edge XANES spectra is 1.84 (Figure S16, Supporting Information), which agrees well with previous results.[24] The high- resolution Cu 3d (Figure S17, Supporting Information) XPS profile also shows that the valence of  $\mathrm{Cu}$  in  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$  SAC was lower than +2. The Fourier transform (FT)  $\mathrm{k}^3$ - weighted  $\chi (k)$  - function of the Cu K- edge EXAFS data in R space shows a single scattering path at  $\approx 1.47\mathrm{\AA}$  for  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$  SAC, which is similar to that for Salen- Cu, assigned to the  $\mathrm{Cu - N / O}$  path. The absence of the  $\mathrm{Cu - Cu}$  scattering path  $(2.24\mathrm{\AA})$  reveals the presence of atomic  $\mathrm{Cu}$  sites in the sample (Figure 4e). However, further distinguishing the coordination paths of  $\mathrm{N}$  and  $\mathrm{O}$  would be challenging because of the similar bond lengths of  $\mathrm{Cu - N}$  and  $\mathrm{Cu - O}$ .[25]

# 2. Results and Discussions

The  $\mathrm{NO}_3\mathrm{RR}$  performance of  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$  was tested in a typical H- cell under ambient conditions in  $0.5\mathrm{MNa}_2\mathrm{SO}_4$  solution containing  $1000\mathrm{ppm}$  of  $\mathrm{N - KNO_3}$  .First, linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) revealed an enhancement in the current density compared to that in the solution without  $\mathrm{KNO_3}$  ,confirming that nitrate could be effectively reduced by  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$  SAC (Figure 5a). The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) was measured through double- layer capacitance method and the current densities were plot as a function of scan rate (Figure S18, Supporting Information). ECSA of  $\mathrm{Cu - cis - N_2O_2}$  was estimated as approximately  $60~\mathrm{cm^2}$  . Upon varying the voltage from  $- 1.0$  to  $- 2.0\mathrm{V}$  (versus RHE hereafter), the ammonia production rate gradually increased, but the selectivity and Faradic efficiency for ammonia production first increased and then decreased (Figure 5b). Thus,  $- 1.6\mathrm{V}$  was selected as the optimal operation voltage. With prolonged reaction time, the concentration of nitrate continuously dropped with  $93.19\%$  conversion at  $^{\textrm{\scriptsize 8h}}$  and that of ammonia gradually increased, obeying first- order kinetics (Figure 5c). This suggests that even at a high nitrate concentration, the reaction rate is sufficiently fast and is only limited by the diffusion of nitrate from the bulk to the electrode surface. Therefore, symmetry- breaking- induced surface accumulation plays a non- trivial role. The concentration of  $\mathrm{NO}_2^-$  first increased and then decreased, maintaining a low production rate. Below  $- 2.0\mathrm{V}$  when the background ammonia production was subtracted from that of the blank  $\mathrm{Na_2SO_4}$  solution, the ammonia production rate reached  $28.73\pm 1.25\mathrm{mg h^{- 1} cm^{- 2}}$  (Figure 5d), and the selectivity and Faradic efficiency for ammonia
